Posts.Content: May 21, 2010 06:34PM alligans wrote: Hello!  Add me to the nipple discharge category.  So far Slyspyder my story is a benign one and hopefully it stays that way.  Last May (09) I did my first breast exam after having a slightly high calcium blood test  months earlier.  Since I couldn't find a reason for the high calcium (which was a one time blip and just a little high...later went on to find that the cause was most likely dehydration) I had convinced myself from reading too much online that I had some kind of cancer, most likely breast since that it pretty much the only thing that I hadn't been tested for due to my age.  Anyway, I did the exam and everything was fine.  A few days later I wantedt to do it again just to be sure.  I found a different set of directions that said to squeeze the nipple.  I think I actually compressed my breast tissue rather than squeezing the nipple.  A small amount of clear, slightly yellow discharge came out and completely freaked me out.  The next day I went to my primary.  She examined me and didn't feel any lumps.  I already knew there were no lumps since I had been checking them non-stop after the discharge incident.  I immediately had a mammogram and ultrasound. Mammogram was negative however my ultrasound found a 1.6 cm solid nodule.  I knew something was up when the ultrasound tech stopped saying, "nothing to worry about" and I wasn't even asking her about it.  I was her measuring a black spot and knew something was up.  When I left I asked her if everything was still ok and she said, "nothing very worrisome".  I left freaking out.  Just the change her wording made me know that she found something.  I convinced myself that it had to be a cyst.  Two days later I got the call.  I nearly collapsed after being told that it was a solid nodule.  I had a core biopsy a few days later and within a week I learned it was a fibroadenoma (benign tumor...common for women in my age group...I'm 33).  I sought a second opinion with a breast surgeon at a breast cancer clinic.  He had his pathologist look over the slides to make sure everything was ok with the first report and everything was.  They also did some more ultrasounds with their breast specialist radiology department to make sure that the original images were good.  This past January I had my follow-up ultrasound and the tumor looks exactly the way it did in May of 09.  I have another check-up witht he surgeon in August.  I don't have an ultrasound appointment but I may ask for one.  Since the core biopsy I've noticed that after I ovulate the area where the tumor is gets tender.  The closer I am to my period, the more tender it gets.  I never noticed this before the biopsy but the biopsy was also pretty painful for me.  I don't think they numbed me very well and I let them know that I was in pain.  I could feel the needle ripping the tissue out of me.  Horrible, but very very very uncommon.  I think this is why I still get the cyclical pain, which is also common with fibroadenomas.  The breast surgeon says that the discharge is normal and that it's due to fibrocystic breasts.  My OB says it's hormonal.  I did notice that if I try hard enough I can get an even smaller amount to come out of the other breast when I squeeze on the exact same spot.   Let me just note that my discharge was never spontaneous and was only bloody for a few days after my biopsy (I had to check if it was still there after I removed the bandages and got freaked out by the brown color).  It went away and hopefully will never come back.  You may want to get a second opinion from another breast specialist just to be sure that everything is ok.  Blood is usually a sign that something is going on (papilloma - benign - most of the time).
Posts.Title: Nipple discharge--when to worry? slyspyder Moderators

Posts.Content: May 22, 2010 06:36PM alligans wrote: Toolie - May I ask you the nature of your discharge?  Bloody?  Clear?  Yellow?  Spontaneous or not?  Sorry for getting personal, but I'm just wondering because I have a small amount of clear to yellow fluid that I can express if I try hard enough and nothing other than a biopsy proven fibroadenoma has ever been found.  Mammo showed dense breasts but I'm young so that's normal.  No MRI only an ultrasound.
Posts.Title: Nipple discharge--when to worry? slyspyder Moderators

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2011 06:05PM alligans wrote: Yay!!!  I am so happy for you!  Welcome to the fibroadenoma club.  I'm on the same type of follow-up protocol. I'm so sorry for your loss.  The past few weeks sound like they have been very hard for you.  Here's what I do to keep my fibroadenoma in line: -Monthly breast exams immediately following my period.  My tumor isn't palable but I know where it is so I am extra vigilant about monitoring that area for any changes. -Maintain my breast surgeon's recommended follow-up schedule.  I don't put off appointments with him.  I also make sure that everytime I see my OBGYN that I remind her about the fibroadenoma so she does an especially good clinical breast exam paying special attention to where the tumor is. -Something you may want to inquire about is getting your vitamin D level checked.  Adequate levels of vitamin D have been linked to a smaller risk of getting breast, colon, and other common cancers.  Before taking vitamin D be sure to get the vitamin D blood test as having too much vitamin D in your body isn't good for you.  You have to ask for this test.  It's not part of your standard work-up. -This is just my personal opinion.  Considering that fibroadenomas are driven by hormones and that studies have shown that starting bc pills at an early age is linked to a higher likihood of developing a fibroadenoma (it's also linked to breast cancer) if you are on any type of bc pill or are considering it you may want to read up on birth control and fibroadenomas or discuss it with your breast surgeon.  Your OB may not be so aware of this link as the focus is usually on breast cancer and birth control pills.
Posts.Title: waiting for biopsy, losing weight gardeeena alligans

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2011 06:56PM - edited Oct 1, 2011 07:00PM by alligans I too have a fibroadenoma and have done considerable reading on this PITA tumor.  I can't feel mine which I wish wasn't the case because I can't monitor it for changes without some type of imaging.  Mine was found on an ultrasound (mammo negative).  Fibroadenomas have a very common appearance on ultrasound (grayish, oval, well circumsribed, distinct boarders - although they can be slighly lobulated aka lumpy looking).  The radiologist reading my ultrasound said she thought it was a fibroadenoma but a biopsy was needed to be sure because sometimes malignant things can initially look benign and vice versa.  The only way to know for 100% what kinds of cells are in a tumor is to biopsy the tumor and then to make sure that the pathology and imagine correlate.  If not, then another biopsy is needed.   Another good reason for biopsying a fibroadenoma is to make sure that it's not a phyllodes (you could call this tumor the fibroadenoma's evil cousin).  Phyllodes and fibroadenomas are similar in appearance on imaging and similar but not the exact same cellular make-up but phyllodes don't behave as nicely (they can get very large over a short period of time and they can also be benign/borderline malignant/ or malignant).  This tumor is a lot rarer than a fibroadenoma but it's one of the reasons that many radiologists like to at least do a core needle biopsy of a tumor that looks like a fibroadenoma. I completely understand your stress.  I have similar stress and my tumor is biopsy proven to be a fibroadenoma.  If you are having a lot of anxiety over the tumor which it sounds like your are having then you need to strongly convince your doctor to biopsy the tumor (even if it hasn't grown).  If the doctor refuses or tells you it's just your anxiety/nerves/stress, etc. leave and find a new breast surgeon.  After the biopsy you should have at least a radiologist but even better a breast surgeon following up at certain intervals.  Initially I was being follwed every 6 months and once it was proven via ultrasound that the tumor remained stable I was switched to yearly follow-ups.  Even though my breast surgeon is against it, I have my OB send me for a yearly ultrasound but no more mammos until I'm 40 due to radiation exposure concerns.  Remember, it's your body and you have every reason to be concerned.  Don't let anyone call you crazy/hypocondriac, etc.  You go with your gut instinct because that little voice in your head that is causing this anxiety will not go away until you have answers.  There is no reason for you to be living with this fear.  Sometimes the anxiety can be more painful than the biopsy (which shouldn't be very painful).  When in doubt...biopsy it (regardless of your age).  PS:  I'm going to assume that the ultrasound tech said the tumor looked dirty because of the gray/whitish specs within the tumor.  Fibroadenomas have a similar shape to some cysts but unlike simple cysts which are solid black on an ultrasound they are speckled with these gray/whitish specs making them look like a complex cyst (meaning a cyst filled with debris or blood).  As long as the tech didn't use the word spiculated try not to read too much into what she said about it looking dirty.  Techs really shouldn't be talking about their findings because they aren't doctors.
Posts.Title: It's Fibroadenoma But I'm Still Scared DreamSweetDreams Swotz

Posts.Content: May 22, 2010 06:42PM alligans wrote: Looking back on what I went through, I'd rather had an excisional.  I had pain with my core which isn't the norm.  My ultrasound showed a benign image and the biopsy proved that, however, I am now stuck with cyclical pain that I never had before the biopsy and a tumor inside of me.  I just wish I hadn't rushed in the heat of the moment and instead that it yanked out.  Now I have 6 month check ups to deal with the make sure that the tumor's image and behavior remains the same.  I say get it over and done with.  If it's proven benign (cores are usually accurate when the pathology matches the image and is monitored over time for  any changes in the image) you'll end up with 6 month follow-ups for a long time.  While I like the idea of 6 month follow-ups just so I have piece of mind that nothing new pops up and my breast get a really good exam every 6 months, it's a PITA and the anxiety that I go through before each of these appointments makes an exicional biospy sound like paradise compared to dealing with this.
Posts.Title: Excisional biopsy vs needle..... catwood kibbles

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 05:42PM alligans wrote: A fibroadenoma is a benign tumor made up of fibrous (fibro) and glandular (adenoma) cells.  They are very common in the under 40 age group.  I believe they are the most common benign breast tumor in this age group.  My fibroadenoma was rated BIRADS 4.  I was 32 at the time.  I think that my radiologist labeled it a 4 because she wanted to see the cells to be certain that it was a fibroadenoma and not a phyllodes or a cancerous tumor mimicing the apperance of a benign tumor.  While fibroadenomas have a very typical ultrasound apperance, there is no way to be 100% certain without a biopsy. At your age, chances are very high that it is a fibroadenoma.  However, it's best to be sure that you're dealing with a fibroadenoma instead of its nasty cousin, the phyllodes (can be benign or malignant...it also tends to grow faster and bigger than a fibroadenoma).  If your biopsy comes back as a fibroadenoma, you will most likely be placed on a 6 month check-up schedule for a year to make sure the tumor doesn't change in its appearance, size, or behavior.  If you have a radiologist doing the biopsy then I'd follow-up with a breast surgeon afterwards so the surgeon will keep a good eye on it for you.  Good luck!  I wouldn't lose too much sleep over this right now.  I did even though everyone was telling me I was getting too worked up over it because chances were that it was fibroadenoma.
Posts.Title: Birads 4 ultrasound, biopsy today jesscr05 BioAdoptMom3

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2010 06:34PM alligans wrote: Yep, I had a similar description of my mass as well.  The shape that they described is a good indicator of it being a fibroadenoma.  I had a core biopsy to correlate pathology to imaging.  Are you going to get a biopsy?  I'd recommend it just to be on the safe side.
Posts.Title: A little update and question kennessee kennessee

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2011 09:05PM alligans wrote: He said you have so many fibroadenomas because you're thin?  I have done extensive reading on fibroadenomas as I have one and never in any general article or in any medical research article have I ever seen that statement.  I'm sorry but from that statement alone I'd say go get yourself a new breast surgeon.  This may sound harsh but that statement sounds like quackery to me.  Being thin doesn't cause the necessary genetic mutations needed for a fibroadenoma to be created.  Fibroadenomas thrive on hormones not a lack of of extra pounds.

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2011 04:46PM alligans wrote: Try to call the doctor and ask for a prescription for a breast ultrasound.  Some lumps only show up on an ultrasound.  My fibroadenoma is nowhere to be found on my mammogram, however, it's clear as day on the ultrasound.  I don't think the doctor needs to see you for you to get this prescription since you've already been seen about the lump.  Explain your concerns and be agressive about asking for the prescription.
Posts.Title: Mammo came back normal but why do I have a lump? poochiewoochie DesignerMom

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2010 12:57PM alligans wrote: Call them back and tell them it's for a diagnostic mammogram and not a screening mammogram.  They may think this is just an ordinary yearly mammogram and thus put you at the end of the line.  If they know it's for diagnostic purposes they should be able to get you an earlier appointment.  This will also put your mammogram on the top of the pile for the radiologist to review.  Screening mammograms aren't read (can take as long as 2 weeks for a report to be made) as fast as the diagnostic ones (usually 24-48 hours). If this doesn't work then try calling a cancer center, preferably one with a breast cancer clinic or center.  Again be sure to point out that this is for diagnostic purposes (even if this is your first one).  Don't assume that the person you are talking to on the phone understands this.  If none of this helps, call your doctor and have her make a request for an earlier appointment.
Posts.Title: scared & have to wait 6 weeks tane05 Letlet

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 04:26PM alligans wrote: My core needle biopsy came back with the same thing...fibroadenomatoid hyperplasia (same thing as fibroadenomatous changes) with focal PASH but I too have a solid nodule that was 1.6 cm.  That's why I knew what you were talking about because I read about it after getting my original pathology report back.  For two weeks I was like, yippie it's the step before a fibroadenoma so maybe it's not technically a tumor. Then I saw my breast surgeon.  He re-did the ultrasound because he said the breast cancer clinic's expert radiologists and technicians can get better images because he likes the pathology to match the radiology.  He said that fibroadenomas tend to move away from the biopsy needle which makes it harder for the needle to get into the fibroadenoma.  When he said that I think he was hinting at the biopsy coming back as fibroadenomatous changes and not a fibroadenoma.  He told me based on what the ultrasound showed, he'd either see me again in 6 months or do another biopsy.  The ultrasound confirmed a fibroadenoma appearing tumor.  He also had the clinic's pathologists looks at my biopsy slides.  I never looked at this pathology report.  I know to always ask to see the pathology but I was scared to maybe read something that would send my anxiety through the roof because I usually leave no leaf unturned.  Six months later when I asked him what his pathologists found he read the new pathology report in front of me and looked up at my eyes and said, "This is defnitely a fibroadenoma.  No cancer."  My theory...since a core biopsy is only a sampling of cells, not the whole tumor, it makes it harder for the pathologist to find all of the necessary characteristics to call it a fibroadenoma.  Fibroadenomatous changes has the common features of a fibroadenoma.  I am 100% sure that the radiologist who did the biopsy hit the tumor because I watched the needle go into the tumor on the ultrasound monitor.  I think this is one of the reasons why when atypical hyperplasia is found the lesion is removed from the breast.  Sometimes, without having the whole tumor pathologists have a hard time differentiating a pre-tumor condition (i.e. hyperplasia) from a tumor.
Posts.Title: Fibroademona questions jalsra alligans

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2010 01:01PM - edited Feb 13, 2010 01:09PM by alligans Please get the biopsy.  It's not bad and the clips are extremely small (can't even put into words how small they are).  You can still get MRIs with them and you'll never know they are there.  You need to have this biopsy done!!!  My friend had to have the same biopsy and she ended up having stage 0 breast cancer.  It was easily removed (thus treated).  If by some off chance that you have breast cancer, it's in an extremely early stage (0) and can be removed and hopefully gone forever from your body.  If you wait 4 months, they will most likely still recommend a biopsy as some cancers are slow and some are fast.  If it's a fast mover and you do nothing it may spread between now and 4 months.  PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE get it done!  My friend was unsure about having it done and after getting her results she was so happy that I pushed her to get it done.  Biopsies aren't pleasant but necessary, especially in your case (what you said about how the microcalcifications look.  From my understanding and I'm not a doctor...it's the ones that look like yours that are more worrysome).  Right now you do not know if you have breast cancer or not.  Only a pathologist who looks at your cells under a slide can determine this.  No mammo, ultrasound, or MRI can 100% diagnoses what cells are there.  It could be normal, it could be some type of hyperplasia which may need to be removed to prevent the cells from turning into cancer, or it could be cancer.  I do not want to scare but I do want to help you and make you aware of possible consequences because this is a terrible disease and I just want help one person avoid making a big mistake.  Women have to help others out.  I don't think that I have breast cancer or at least have not been diagnosed with it either (I have a benign tumor and was asking for advice about removal and increased risk which is why I'm here) .  <any many many times these come back benign and this is what I told my friend but I was wrong in her case.  She did have a very early stage cancer (this is when they are most curable).  You do not be the one who 4 months later wishes she could turn back time and get it done 4 months earlier to fix something that was very fixable and may be much harder to fix 4 months down the road.  I'm sorry if what I write upsets you.  I just want to help.  Please get the biopsy for your health and for your children if you have any.
Posts.Title: 3rd Stereotatic Biopsy sue2008 alligans

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2011 10:23AM alligans wrote: I too have a fibroadenoma.  Mine hasn't been removed although the pathology was confirmed 2x at my insistance.  They are harmless lumps.  My personal advice would be to remove it.  This darn thing has caused me more anxiety than you could ever imagine.  I just watched my dad die for stage 4 kidney/colon cancer (nobody was sure which cancer caused his mets) and I do not want to ever be in that position.  When I see my BS in August I'm going to ask him to get rid of it.  My friend had a lumpectomy for DCIS and she made the whole thing sound like a breeze.  Her procedure actually sounded less painful than my core biopsy.
Posts.Title: Fibroademona questions jalsra alligans

Posts.Content: alligans wrote: Hi!  I have a question about benign fibroadenoma follow-ups.  (this is a double post...posted in the not diagnosed forum but didn't get a response)  Last year I went to my primary care doctor (I have since changed primary care doctors) with the complaint of nipple discharge.  I had never done a self exam at home (I'm 33) and decided it was time to do one.  The right breast was perfectly find.  With the left one I felt nothing odd or out of place (I am small breasted) but the instructions said to squeeze the nipple.  I did and a little bit of fluid came out of a single duct.  I did this again over the next 2 days and sometimes I'd get a little bit of fluid and other times nothing.  The instructions said to immediately report anything abnormal to your doctor so I did.  By the way, this fluid never comes out on it's own...I  have to squeeze a bit to get it to come out.  My primary care doctor did a breast exam on both breasts and said that she felt nothing abnormal.  She checked my prolactin level (well within normal range) and sent me for a mammogram and ultrasound.  Right breast was normal on both tests.  Left mammogram was normal but the ultrasound found a 1.6 cm solid nodule at 3 o'clock, 3 cm from my nipple.  I got a BIRADS of 4 and was sent on for a ultrasound guided core biopsy.  The impression on the ultrasound was fibroadenoma.  A few days later the radiology center did the biopsy.  I watched everything and the needle definitely penetrated the nodule.  The radiologist took 4 samples.  He said that it definitely looks like a fibroadenoma and agrees with the first radiologist's impression but the needed to be 100% sure.  The pathology comes back as fibroadenoma changes with PASH (focal psuedoangiomatous hyperplasia).  My primary care doctor told me that it's a fibroadenoma and I need another ultrasound in 6 months.  When I got a copy of the pathology report I became concerned about the PASH so I went to my OB who told me that focal means very little and not to be worried.  She said that my pathology report isn't scary and that she's seen many that are scary.  She said to relax and just be sure that I go to the 6 month follow-up.  I wanted to be 100% sure so I contacted the university hospital by my house that has a great breast center.  I went there.  I saw a surgeon and nurse.  He wanted another ultrasound done by their experts becaues they can get better images.  I had that done 2 weeks later.  The radiologist came in and did it herself and the technician initally did it.  They were having a hard time seeing the clip that was put in during the biopsy.  He said that they aren't impressed by the images (not being impressed being a good thing in doctor lingo) and to come back in 6 months.  I did that and the tumor has remained completely unchanged.  The technician said it looks exactly the same way it did 6 months ago.  I also asked her to show me where it is because I cannot feel it which is weird because it's 1.6 cm and my breasts are small to begin with.  She told me to wait so the radiologist can look at the images.  She came back 15 minutes later with a piece of paper telling me to come back until I'm 40 because there are no signs of malignancy.   My question is, does this sound ok?  I have no idea how long the fibroadenoma has been there since nobody can actually feel it (I get a yearly check-up from my OB).  Maybe it's been in there for 10 years, who knows.  It hasn't changed in 6 months so is it ok to ignore it until I'm 40 or should I go for another 6 month check-up just to be sure.  I'm thinking that since this is well known breast center on Long Island that they probably know best since they deal with this everyday but in the back on my mind I'm questioning whether or not I should ask my OB for a check-up in another 6 months just to be sure.  I always tend to question medical opinions and really don't want a bad surprise when I go back at 40. Thank you. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Question about a fibroadenoma alligans annikamolander

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2010 11:09AM alligans wrote: I can't help you too much as to what it could be that they are looking for.  Hopefully it's nothing. Focal means small area of concentration vs. diffuse which means wide spread. Assymetry means that whatever they are comparing it to whether it me another area of your breast or the other breast means that the two do not look similar or are not even.  They may be describing breast density, possibly an area of skin thickening although they'd probably say skin thickening instead of what you just wrote, or some sort of distortion in the breast's architecture.  Think of it as looking at two straight lines where one line is completely straight and the other has a little bulge in it that the other doesn't have.  Best of luck!  Hopefully it's nothing major.  At this point, don't worry too much.  Get the callback and go from there as it can mean any number of things.
Posts.Title: what is focal assymetry verynervous alligans

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2010 12:00PM alligans wrote: On ultrasound: Simple cyst will show up as a solid black round and smooth appearing lesion.  A complex cyst's imaging will be similar to that of a tumor but there must be some sort of differentiation but I do not know what that is.  The solid parts of the complex cyst will created speckles within the smooth round lesion. A tumor can be of any shape or form depending on whether it's most likely benign or most likely malignant.  However, the lesion will not be solid black.  There will be internal hyperechos creating a lesion that looks a little bit gray or sort of like black and white static that you see on your TV.
Posts.Title: Cyst Question deadra alligans

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2010 04:51AM - edited Feb 9, 2010 05:11AM by alligans I've decided to go back to the breast surgeon after reading your stories.  They did scare me but that's a good thing.  I tend to be proactive but I also tend to have healthy and cancer anxiety and overanalyze and worry obsessively about these things.  I am trying to stay calm because things look very good for me right now but I don't want to make a stupid decision that I will regret down the road.   Sooo...I'm back at the worrying stage again.  I see the surgeon on Monday, the 15th to see if he will remove the fibroadenoma so I don't worry about it for 7 years.   About a month after the biopsy I noticed 3 swollen nodes in my cervical neck.  I know they weren't there in April (long story but my neck was checked via ultrasound because I was concerned about something).  They haven't grown and are most likely still swollen because I touch them to make sure they are staying the same or getting smaller.  They have gotten smaller since I found them but are still touchable.  They are around 1 cm...possibly slightly smaller.  This set off fears of lymphoma so one node was FNA biospied with no malignant cells found just a reactive node.  I also had a CT scan of my neck (which showed everything in my head from my eye balls down to part of the supraclavicular ares).  Nothing abnormal but the 3 nodes which the radiologist didn't think much of.  The breast surgeon wasn't aware of this as I saw it as a completely different issue.  He did check my armpit nodes and supraclavicular area but not my cervical neck.  Now I'm starting to wonder if these nodes are connected to my fibroadenoma.  I was wondering if a tumor that looks benign, is core biopsied as benign and has remained unchanged could actually me a type of breast cancer that has spread to my neck nodes.  The tumor looks exactly like it did in May 09 so I'm guessing that it isn't possible.  I'm guessing that a metastic breast tumor would look different after 6 months.  Is this a good guess or a bad one?  Ughhh...I hate anything medical.  My life has been a mess since my doctor found a calcium level of  10.4 in January 09.  After reading about high calcium I flipped out emotionally and anxiety has gotten a strong grip on me.  My PTH was smack tab in the middle or normal and the calcium never to anything above 10.2 again.  At last check it was 9.6 which the hematologist/oncologist told me is a good indication that the high calcium wasn't caused by a malignancy becasue the calcium with continue to be high (it's been checked numerous times at my insistance).  I saw the hematologist after nagging my primary about the swollen nodes, lymphoma, and my fear of the calcium indicating a malginancy.  Every doctor I've seen who has looked at and touched the nodes is well aware of the calcium issue and the fibroadenoma issue.  I feel like such a medical mess that is in limbo all of the time.  Everytime I see a doctor the first thing they diagnose me with is anxiety.  I've been politely kicked out of 3 ENT offices and an endocrinology office (another long story but nothing is wrong with my thyroid which has been checked 3 times).  In the past year I've had a colonoscopy, 2 back MRIs for a backache that eventually went away, a back x-ray before the MRI but I wasn't satisfied, numerous blood tests (numerous CBCs, numerous liver panels, metabolic, PTH, LDH, ESR or Sed rate, urinalysis, 3 pelvic ultrasounds for a small cyst, that went away, prolactin for the discharge, von Willebrands, bleeding time, 3 neck ultrasounds, a neck CT, abdominal and renal ultrasound, lymph node FNA, skin biopsy because the dermatologist was arguing with me that I cluster of spots on me was not petechiae when in fact the biopsy proved him wrong, 3 mammograms...1 for a diagnosis, 1 post clip insertion, and 1 because the breast center couldn't get a hold of my orignal mammogram, 5 breast ultrasounds...1 for diagnosis, 1 during core biopsy, 1 two months after the biopsy because I was still feeling pain from it where no pain existed prior, and 2 from the breast center to diagnose and follow-up).  From all of this, nothing abnormal except for a minimally elevated calcium level which never reared its ugly head again and a fibroadenoma.  I'm scared to death and am sick of being told that I'm anxious.  I know I'm anxious...I live with it daily.  If someone would just get rid of the fibroadenoma so I can be sure that I'm ok and get rid of one of the nodes so I know that I'm ok then I'd be able to get on with my life.  I feel like I've aged 5 years in this past year from all of the worry that the orignal calcium test caused.   Ladies, I'm sorry I went on and on but maybe someone on here can relate and help me sort through this because it's been inside of me for a year and I am not getting much help from the specialists I've seen.  My primary doctor has been great but he is starting to think I'm nuts too and is only sending me off to these specialists with the hopes of reassurance that I'm ok.  He looked into my eyes twice and said, "I don't think anything is wrong with you".   I read so many misdiagnosis stories on here and on the lymphoma board and I fear that I am being misdiagnosed about one of these conditions because nobody will cut these things out of me.  I've so had it.  I don't trust most doctors because if they can't find it they assume you're nuts and don't want to listen to my concerns.  My family has had it with me which at this point I understand.  I've had it with me too but I can't get these stories out of my mind.  Most likely I'm not one of these stories but I don't want to regret later what I could have fixed sooner. Any advice or help? Thank you so much.  It feels good to finally get my concerns out in the open.  If anyone can relate me help me sort through this.  You can PM if you want.
Posts.Title: Question about a fibroadenoma alligans annikamolander

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2010 12:33PM alligans wrote: Good evening ladies.  I had my yearly exam with my OBGYN and discussed the fibroadenoma with her to see her take on it.  She agreed that waiting 7 years is way too long.  She got my ultrasound report from Stony Brook's breast clinic and read it.  I looked over her shoulder and could only see "1.6 cm stable fibroadenoma..."  She said that she wants to image it once a year.  She tried to feel it and knew where it was but couldn't actually feel the lump due to the thick dense tissue covering it up.  I asked her about the nipple discharge and she said that it's due to my hormones.  As long as my prolactin level is normal (it is...very very normal according to my bloodwork from May) and as long as nothing else was found on the mammo or ultrasound that it must be hormonal.  I'm not sure that I agree with that.  I'm going to post a question about the discharge in another thread.  She doesn't know that I'm also consulting with a breast surgeon at Stony Brook on Monday.  I wanted an unadulterated professional opinion.
Posts.Title: Question about a fibroadenoma alligans annikamolander

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2010 09:21PM - edited Sep 1, 2010 09:22PM by alligans If what he's seeing is in fact a fatty hilum then it is indeed a lymph node.  At 1.7 cm it sounds like it may be swollen.  Have you been touching that particular area a lot since learning of the lump?  Excessive touching, poking, or proding of a lymph node can cause it to swell or to remain swollen for a very long time. Lymph nodes swell for a large variety of benign reasons but they can also swell from cancer (I'm not saying you have cancer).  You will most likely notice the ones in your neck swell when you have a fever, sore throat, cold, nasal drip, infection in your throat such as strep, scalp infection, a virus, allergies, and even bad bouts with acne.  Most of the time lymph nodes swell for benign reasons.  Anything over 1.5 cm in most areas is concerning if the lymph node remains swollen for longer than a month.  Anything over 2 cm warrants a biopsy if it does get smaller within 2-3 weeks.  A lymph node that is hard and/or immobile (attached to underlying tissue) warrants an immediate biopsy regardless of size or location when there is no visible fever or illness present.  The cancers that would be concerning to a swollen lymph node in your breast would be breast cancer and lymphoma.  However, since the radiologist could see the fatty hilum your lymph node is most likely benign.  The average human has 500-700 lymph nodes running thoughout their body.  Their job is to keep your body safe.  They collect any crap (germs, infections, bacteria, virus, fungus, cancer cells) and swell up because the lymph node rapidly produces lymphocytes (immune system cells called B cells and T cells) to fight off whatever is trapped in the lymph node.  Excessive touching can cause them to swell as well (I learned this the hard way).  The radiologist wants to biopsy your lymph node for 2 reasons:  A - to make sure it's a lymph node and B - to see if it contains cancer cells.  I had a FNA of a neck lymph node about 1 year ago and it was a little bit of an ouch but nothing bad.  If your doctor is concerned about lymphoma, I'd highly suggest an excisional biopsy as lymphoma is a very hard thing to diagnose and there are literally 40 different varients.  However, a visible fatty hilum (if the words of an endocrinologist that I saw who did a neck ultrasound on me himself) is very reassuring that lymphoma isn't the case. One more thing, if by some odd chance it's not a lymph node, the term circumscribe to describe a breast tumor is usually indicative of a benign pathology but biopsy is needed to be 100% sure. Good luck!  Wishing B9 results for you.

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2011 08:00PM alligans wrote: What you describe can definitely be fibrocystic changes as well as fibroadenoma-like changes.  It's common for your age.  I'm the same age and have been told the same thing as I have cyclical discomfort right at the point of ovulation.  This discomfort is where my fibroadenoma is (this is the step after fibroadenoma-like changes...but this doesn't mean that you'll get a fibroadenoma).  If you are concerned then seek out a second opinion.  Try to go to a breast cancer clinic within a cancer center.
Posts.Title: Question about Fibrocystic Change CUGymGirl Jaydra

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2010 09:40AM - edited Feb 9, 2010 09:45AM by alligans Thank you Cath.  I don't think that I've ever read of a fibroadenoma growing around a tumor (I've heard of the reverse in the margins but never this) and that's quite a combination of evil cells you have.  I hope that your treatment is going well for you.  I haven't read too much on this board (just enough to scare me into being more proactive about this tumor) so I'm not familiar with your posts.  Everyone tends to do the age thing...you're too young so it isn't possible.  I've read far too many stories of people not being within the usual age and getting this.  Cancer doesn't know your age and doesn't care.  If 1 bad cell decided to wreak havoc then you have to kick it in its butt no matter what your age is.  Cancer doesn't discriminate based on age, regardless of all of the stupid stats.  There is always someone in the minority and anyone, including oneself, can be in the minority.  Cancer doesn't care who you are, if you have children, if you're 18 or 90.  This is what I've learned and this is why I fight my doctors on everything.  I don't like stats.  There are always 2 sides to them and nobody knows which side of the stats you'll be on.  That is what I keep telling my family, just because I have anxiety about this stuff doesn't necessarily mean that I don't have it.  My family history is negative for BC but on my mom's side there are 2 cancers both of which were from smoking after being told to quit.  I don't smoke and never have so I don't think I'm at risk for either of those...bladder and throat.   I told my husband that I just want him to hold my hand through this process.  He wants to fix it, the it being the anxiety.  I told him that he can't fix it and that he doesn't need to.  I just want someone to hold my hand and give me emotional support instead of trying to psychoanalyze me, which is definitely isn't qualified to do.   I hope that all of this is just my anxiety getting the better of me, but I'm from the school of better safe than sorry.
Posts.Title: Question about a fibroadenoma alligans annikamolander

Posts.Content: May 17, 2010 08:33PM alligans wrote: Bagira, from one lymph node obsessed person to another...high five girl!  You know your stuff!  The only thing that I can add is that you may want to push for an excisional biopsy of the nodes if breast cancer has been ruled out because lymphoma can also show up as a reactive lymph node with a needle biopsy.  BTW, I'm not saying that  you have lymphoma.  Things to watch out for are...hard immobile lymph nodes, increasing number of swollen lymph nodes, and increasing size of swollen lymph nodes.  After my breast cancer scare (benign tumor) I ended up having a lymphoma scare so I'm well read on both diseases.  After several months, I can still feel my swollen lymph nodes (in my neck) but they are actually going away (yay!).  After the breast cancer scare, I freaked out and started feeling my neck for lymph nodes one day and found some.  I kept playing with them non-stop over the course of a very anxious weekend and ended up irrirating them into a big size (almost 2 cm).  I had a FNA of one of the swollen nodes and it came back as benign reactive.  I kept pushing a bunch of ENTs to remove one but none would.  I even went to a hematologist to get his take on the swollen nodes.  Everyone told me to stop touching them and to get scared if they grew.  They never grew (knock on wood) and I've been leaving them alone for a couple of weeks and they are getting smaller.  So, my advice is not to touch them because if they are just reacting to something then touching them will only keep them swollen.  How large are the swollen lymph nodes?  Their size should be indicated on the radiologist's report.  Anything under 1 cm is usually just an infection or virus.  1 cm - 2 cm is more worrisome but still within the most likely benign range unless they keep getting bigger or NEVER get smaller (over the course of a few months).  2 cm + should be a red flag!  FNA are usually very good when looking for metastic cancer such as breast cancer however they aren't so good when looking for lymphoma.  If lymphoma and breast cancer have been ruled out at this point then follow up with another ultrasound in a few months to see if they have changed in size.  You may also want to palpatate your neck, supraclavicular (collar bone), and groin for swollen nodes.  Also take your temperature to see if you're funning a fever.
Posts.Title: Lymph Nodes on Ultrasound? Melimerri MTwoman

Posts.Content: May 24, 2010 09:33AM - edited May 24, 2010 09:36AM by alligans Well, PASH could be 2 different things.  Originally PASH was found in my fibroadenoma pathology but it was later removed when my slides were looked over by another pathologist. In my case the PASH was listed as focal which means very small amount.  This is a common incidental finding in biopsies and doesn't really mean much of anything.  Just another type of hyperplasia and is benign.  However, there are rare instances when the PASH makes up the whole tumor.  This is very rare although it does happen.  Again, it's benign as long as the pathologist knows his stuff.  Like another poster mentioned, it can be mistaken for angiosarcoma which is a very aggressive but rare type of cancer.  It differs from most breast cancers which are carcinomas.  I think in this instance the most important thing is making sure that it's not an angiosarcoma because pathologically the two can be mistaken for each other.  In layman's terms, pseudo means that it looks like one thing but it actually isn't it.  In this case, it means that it looks like angiosarcoma but it isn't and it isn't malignant.  My layman's wording may make this sound malignant but it's not as long as the pathology is correct.  You may want to get the slides checked over by another pathologist (at a breast cancer center) just to be sure since this is a pretty rare thing (having it as a whole tumor rather than just an incidental finding).
Posts.Title: What is PASH? Meaghan alligans

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2011 04:08AM alligans wrote: Macismommy - During the year following the discovery of the fibroadenoma I was checked every 6 months.  During the first 6 month check-up I had another ultrasound in addition to seeing the breast surgeon.  My fibroadenoma was also a tad smaller and they said that was due to the biopsy removing a little bit of the tumor but by a tad bit smaller it really wasn't of any significance.  I only say this because sometimes as we get older (usually after menopause) the fibroadenomas get smaller because the hormones that they were thriving on are no longer in our bodies in the amounts they used to be. During the second 6 month check-up he didn't order another ultrasound and just did a clinical breast exam.  I asked him about another ultrasound and he said it wasn't necessary as the tumor is stable.  I wasn't too happy with that response.  He then graduated me to a 12 month follow-up so I will see him again this summer.  In March I am going for my yearly OB exam so I will ask her to order an ultrasound.  She told me before that she had no problem doing that and agreed that the tumor should be looked at yearly.  In October I will turn 35 so I'm pondering whether or not I should ask for another mammogram.  My first mammogram didn't show the fibroadenoma.  The mammogram came back as completely normal.  It was the ultrasound that found the tumor (which by the way cannot be felt by anyone and I'm small breasted).  I think that due to my age I may just ask for a bilateral ultrasound.  The younger you are, the more dense your breast tissue is which is why mammogram screenings usually begin at 40.  Why get a dose of radiation if it's not going to do anything.
Posts.Title: Fibroademona questions jalsra alligans

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2010 04:04PM alligans wrote: I'm not a doctor but here's my take (I have a fibroadenoma)... 1. Your lump in the right breast does sound characteristic of a fibroadenoma.  Mine appeared on the ultrasound but not on the mammogram.  I can't feel it.  After the ultrasound picked it up (and the report said that it is a fibroadenoma), the radiology report said to biopsy it to be 100% sure.  You sound very nervous about this lump so you should push for a biopsy just to be sure.  You can have a core biopsy (but even with that,  you'll still be on the 6 month follow up schedule.  I am and every 6 months I go through lots of anxiety).  An excisional biopsy would give you a 100% answer as to what it is.  Core is very accurate, especially when the pathology matches the image and follow up shows a stable lesion.  2.  Are the calcifications located where the breast pain is?  If so, you may want to push for a biopsy of them to just to be sure that nothing is "cooking" in there.  Breast pain has many benign causes but it can also signify something more serious which is why, IMO, it should be taken seriously and not be ignored until everything has been ruled out.  If you're still getting your period, this pain could be caused from hormones.  If it doesn't go away after you get your period then take that as a red flag and get it further investigated. I have health anxiety which has been getting better over time.  However, after my biopsy I was very anxious over my fibroadenoma.  I decided that the best thing I could do for myself was to find a breast surgeon at a breast cancer center to watch over the fibroadenoma.  He redid the ultrasound and had his pathology people look over my slides to be sure that everything equated to a fibroadenoma.  I see him every 6 months.  Fibroadenomas are benign.  They do not turn malignant.  Sometimes, malignant cells can hide out in the tissues inside of a fibroadenoma or in the tissue surrounding the fibroadenoma.  There are at least 2 women on here who had this.  However, that's the minority.  Most of the time fibroadenomas cause no harm and have no malignant potential.  However, you need to be sure that it's a fibroadenoma.  This is a very common lesion in younger women, but it may just be something that's been in your breast for years that you just never noticied.  I can't even feel mine.  However, you need some pathology to be sure that it's a fibroadenoma.  Sometimes, fibroadenomas can look like another tumor called phyllodes tumors.  Some phyllodes tumors are benign and some are malignant (strage wording but I've only read a little bit about this tumor so I don't know about this gray area tumor).  With a fibroadenoma-like lesion appearing on a mammogram or ultrasound, the biggest concern is it actually being a phyllodes which is why a biopsy is usually done.  Also, not to scare you but so to educate you in helping you to make a decision, sometimes benign appearing things can actually be malignant and sometimes malignant appearing things can be benign.  I'm not a doctor, but I think that any lump appearing in the breast should be biopsied so that you are sure what you're dealing with.  I'm surprised that the radiologist didn't recommend this.
Posts.Title: STUPID! georgie_girl wyldblumusic

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2010 03:15AM alligans wrote: Make sure you get a breast ultrasound in addition to a mammo.  Due to your young age, your breasts are most likely dense (as are mine at 33) which can make it hard for radiologists to find any abnormalies on the mammo because the dense tissue hides these things. Although not 100% accurate, at your age there will be a better chance for the radiologist to find whatever you're feeling.  I have a benign tumor called a fibroadenoma and it wasn't seen on my mammo which came back as normal but it was found via ultrasound and it's 1.6 cm (not that small but not huge either).  Good luck and I hope that everything turns out benign for you (chances are good due to your age but you still need to get this checked out as 22 year olds can get breast cancer...albeit rare).
Posts.Title: I found a lump... now what? lexigirl lexigirl

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2012 10:47PM - edited Aug 15, 2012 10:50PM by alligans What kind of biopsy did you have?  The pain could be any number of things from injured tissue to an infection or possibly something else .  Do you have a fever?  Is the area where the biopsy done red, inflamed, swollen, or warm to the touch?  If so, it could be an infection. I had a biopsy in 2009.  Before the biopsy my breast never hurt.  My biopsy was in May and I was still hurting in July.  It was especially bad during my period.  One day while at the park I leaned against a playset and I was like, "Ouch".  I decided that that may not be normal and called the radiologist who did my core biopsy.  He said that he had never gotten a call like this before.  He wanted to examine me and he wanted me to get an ultrasound just to make sure that it wasn't an infection, hematoma, or something else.  I  had the ultrasound and everything looked ok.  Eventually the pain went away.  Once in a while it will be a little achey but nothing major.  Usually my period has something to do with it.  I have no idea what is causing this but it's definitely from the biopsy as I never noticed this before. The best thing to do is to call the person who performed your biopsy just to be sure that everything is a-ok. Edit:  Just saw that your doctor is on vacation.  Are there any other doctors in the practice that could examine you?  Perhaps your OB could see you?  Just a warning, my OB's office is very lawsuit paranoid for some reason.  They wanted nothing to do with me since they did not do the biopsy.  The stupid office manager was very nasty to me on the phone but I eventually convinced her that I needed to be seen by a doctor.  I ended up getting hold of the radiologist (I didn't think they saw patients) and he examined me.  If none of this is possible, maybe there is a walk in clinic that takes your insurance?

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2010 09:25PM alligans wrote: Let your mind tell you what to do.  You are very worried and you aren't happy with what your current doctor is offering in terms of diagnosis/reassurance and tests.  This is your mind telling you to get a second opinion.  Different doctors have different approaches.  I always say, run away from the doctor who is pushing your concerns aside.  Try to go to a breast surgeon who is affiliated with a breast cancer clinic.
